Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2013 02:27PM carpe_diem wrote: I can't swear that it's made any difference, but I was impressed by the statistics that women in Asian countries that eat a traditional diet - no dairy, not much meat or fish, lots of veggies - have a much lower rate of breast cancer. They think of bc as the "rich woman's disease" since women there who can afford a more western diet, and asian women who move to the West and change their eating habits, have bc rates closer to western women.  I stopped eating red meat, processed foods, and dairy, and added a lot of whole grains, fruits, veggies, and nuts.  I thought it would be really hard, but there are tons of good recipes out there, and you can always find something to eat out at a restaurant, especially asian. Yes, vegans get bc, but at a much lower rate.  We can't control our genes, but controlling diet and exercise have given me a measure of control.  I've lost 80 lbs, and I'm in much better shape.  It may be supporting my treatment, but even if it's not, it's healthy in many ways and reduces the chance of diabetes and heart disease. There are lots of decent substitutes for dairy.  I used to eat a lot of cheese and I still miss it, but I don't miss the 80 pounds.  I use organic when it tastes better, like tomatoes, and mostly eat organic or wild poultry and fish (and not much of that) but I don't feel deprived, and I do feel much healthier. Posts.Content: May 31, 2013 03:31PM carpe_diem wrote: Arimidex and femara are similar in the way they act, but tamoxifen, which has been around a lot longer, is different. Both Arimidex and tamoxifen work by exerting an effect on estrogen, which feeds the majority of breast cancers and helps them grow. Arimidex belongs to a class of drugs called aromatase inhibitors, which limit the amount of estrogen the body produces in postmenopausal women. Arimidex works by preventing the conversion of steroids made by the adrenal gland into estrogen.  In a woman who has gone through menopause, the adrenal gland is the largest source of estrogen. Arimidex doesn't work in women who are premenopausal because their ovaries make most of their estrogen.  Tamoxifen belongs to a class of drugs called selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs), which work by blocking estrogen from binding to its receptors in the breast. This drug works as well in both premenopausal and postmenopausal women, but the AIs (aromatase inhibitors like arimidex and femara) seem to be more effective, but can lead to reduced bone density.  For post-menopausal metastatic women, taking arimidex first and then switching to tamoxiphen resulted in longer survival than starting with tamoxifen and then switching to arimidex. I've been on arimidex for 27 months, since being diagnosed with lung mets, and the mets were greatly reduced until my last PET/CT.  That showed increased activity in a new area, but I have no symptoms and my tumor markers are stable at about 38 for CA 27-29.  My mo is considering a switch to faslodex, which targets and degrades the estrogen receptors present in breast cancer cells, but we're waiting (nervously on my part) for another PET/CT in August, in the hopes that the last one was just showing lingering effects of radiation, which I finished in March.

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2013 06:40PM carpe_diem wrote: Linda, Nodules in the lung are pretty common and can be the result of previous or current infection, but with a bc dx, you should keep track of them. Mine were dismissed by my pulmonologist for over a year, even with pleural effusions, but after bc was finally diagnosed I had a PET/CT to have another look at them. Even though they showed increased uptake, it was still considered possible that they were not related to the bc, since no cancer cells had been found when they drained the pleural effusions. The deciding factor was a lung biopsy that showed cancer cells like the ones found in my breast biopsy. If you don't have any shortness of breath and there's no fluid around the lungs on your scans, they will probably just watch and wait. If you do develop symptoms, a PET/CT would give more info, but only a lung biopsy would be definitive. It's stressful to just monitor them, but lung biopsies are a lot harder than breast and you'll want to wait until it's really necessary. I hope you can find a good pulmonologist. Maybe your mo has a recommendation.

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2014 06:20PM carpe_diem wrote: jab, I had some pleural nodules that showed up on a CT scan for another issue and was referred to a pulmonologist since I had had two other cancers.  He was about to discharge me after a year because there was no significant change when the last scan showed a large pleural effusion. Testing the fluid removed (twice) showed no malignancy or any other cause and every doctor I asked said it couldn't possibly be related to the blob in my breast that didn't show up on mammograms or ultrasound and was believed to be a cyst.  They all said I was fine, come back in a year.  My PCP was unconvinced and sent me to a thoracic surgeon for a lung biopsy, but he said the nodules weren't large enough to biopsy and I should wait a few months for another scan.  By then my nipple had inverted, they decided I did, indeed have breast cancer, and ordered a PET/CT to see if the pleural effusion had been related.  Well naturally all those little nodules I'd been told were normal lit up and I was sent back to the same thoracic surgeon for a biopsy.  He had the nerve to tell me that I had "refused" the biopsy earlier, but now that I had PET scan results, he had no objection to the biopsy, which showed breast cancer cells essentially the same as the breast biopsy. Don't ask me why he could perform the biopsy now that was impossible a few months earlier. My point is that all the tests I'd had previously were read as normal and it wasn't until I had the PET/CT that cancer of any kind in the lungs was diagnosed.  It may be true that once you have the diagnosis of metastasis, CT scans can be used to follow them, but in my case there was a clear value in the PET/CT for diagnosing them in the first place.

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2013 03:15AM carpe_diem wrote: Apparently lung nodules are not always easy to diagnose.  I was followed for a lung nodule (about 0.5 cm) in my right lung that showed up on a scan for a different condition.  After two years with no change, the pulmonologist was ready to discharge me, when the last CT scan showed a pleural effusion and nodular thickening in the left lung.  Tests of the fluid removed (twice) showed no sign of malignancy, or any other reason for being there, and he assured me that there was no connection with the blob in my left breast that didn't show up on mammogram or ultrasound.  My PCP wasn't convinced and sent me to a thoracic surgeon, but he also tried to tell me that there was nothing seriously abnormal, and I agreed to wait a few months for another scan since the nodules were not large enough for a biopsy.  By that time, the tumor in my breast had progressed enough to invert the nipple and I was suddenly taken a lot more seriously.  Once it was determined that the supraclavicular node was also involved, I had a PET/CT that showed activity in the lung, along with multifocal bc.  At this point the same surgeon that hadn't wanted to do a biopsy earlier went in and a sampling of the nodules showed bc related to the tumors in my breast. Between the mammograms that showed nothing and two pleural effusions with no explanation, it was 10 months before my final diagnosis with stage 4 bc.   Maybe it made no difference - 28 months later I'm still here and doing well - but I doubt that waiting that long for treatment improved the situation.   If your nodules showed up on a CT scan, I'd certainly think a PET/CT would be in order.  If the nodules light up, it could still be some kind of infection and not metastases, but it might convince your doctors to schedule a biopsy.  This is a lot more serious surgery than a breast biopsy, depending on the location of the nodules, but it's the only way to be sure.  I agree that getting your questions answered is the first step, but if your mo is not being helpful, a second opinion from a national cancer center is worth looking into.

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2014 01:12PM carpe_diem wrote: If you read the fine print on the mammogram report, 4-8% of tumors don't show up, and my mo told me that about half of these aren't seen on ultrasound.  Obviously negative is usually good news, but there are some varieties of breast cancer that aren't easily detected.  My tumors are mostly mucinous and didn't show up on regular mammograms. When I felt a blob it was still negative on diagnostic mammogram and ultrasound. The good news about mucinous bc is that it's usually slow growing and rarely metastasizes. The bad new for me is that once in a while it does. It took me ten months to get a diagnosis and by that time the changes in my breast, notably an inverted nipple, were enough to get some attention. I had some dull achiness in the affected breast, but my  other physical problems were due to spread to supraclavicular nodes and lungs, which are not typical in this form of cancer.  There may be other varieties that are not easily detected and with all your symptoms you should certainly press for some answers.  If you have any way of getting insurance, this is the time.  Insurance premiums have got to be cheaper than the tests you'll probably need. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2016 10:03AM carpe_diem wrote: This popped up on cancernetwork recently and I've been mulling it over ever since. I can't get hold of the original paper without spending $40, but if anyone has access I'd really like to know more. As I read it, I have most of the indications for a poor prognosis with an average survival of 12 months. It's been nearly five years since my official dx which came ten months after I started having symptoms (my tumor didn't show up on mammogram or ultrasound and the fluid drained from my pleural effusions showed no cancer (or anything else). I have read elsewhere that in general a longer time before recurrence predicts a longer survival with mbc, which would indicate that de novo mvc is bad news. Risk Prediction Model Could Guide Metastatic Breast Cancer Decisions News | February 04, 2016 | Breast Cancer By Dave Levitan A novel prediction model can help predict long-term overall survival among breast cancer patients with distant metastases, according to a new study. The model could be used as a decision-making tool for physicians and patients. "A reliable prediction of the expected survival in breast cancer patients with distant metastasis is a critical basis for appropriate treatment selection," wrote study authors led by Hyeong-Gon Moon, MD, PhD, of Seoul National University College of Medicine in South Korea. "However, accurate prediction of survival in a newly diagnosed metastatic breast cancer patient is one of the most difficult challenges that physicians face." To develop a method to address that challenge, the researchers analyzed data from 547 patients at a single institution; a validation cohort of 254 additional patients from four Korean teaching hospitals was also included. The results were published online ahead of print in Annals of Oncology. Based on the initial cohort, a post-metastasis overall survival (PMOS) score was developed that ranged from 0 to 8. It included six factors with varying weight: primary tumor stage, hormone receptor (HR) status, and Ki-67 expression level; and metastasis-specific factors including the duration of disease-free interval, the site of the metastasis, and the presence of symptoms related to the metastatic site. The median duration of the PMOS in the full cohort was 31 months, and each of those factors was an independent prognostic factor for PMOS. (Tumor stage and PMOS were only significantly associated in those with early relapses.) The patients were divided into four PMOS score groups; some of the higher risk characteristics that raised a patient's score included brain or multiple metastatic sites, high Ki-67 expression, and HR positivity. "The PMOS score in patients with distant metastasis clearly separated groups of different survival outcomes (P < .0001)," the authors wrote. The patients in the group with the lowest PMOS score (0 or 1) had a median survival of 71 months, compared with only 12 months for those in the group with the highest scores (6 to 8). The score "successfully predicted the post-metastasis survival" in the validation cohort as well, with the two highest groups showing significantly poorer survival than the lowest (P < .0001). Those patients with higher scores, the authors wrote, "are unlikely to benefit from intensive multidisciplinary therapy aimed at clinical remission since their disease may progress rapidly."  PS I'm only glad that I immediately changed from the onc who seemed to agree that I was "unlikely to benefit from intensive multidisciplinary therapy aimed at clinical remission since their disease may progress rapidly" and switched to a doctor who felt I was worth treating and eventually having a mastectomy. I now have lung, bone, and liver mets, but I feel pretty well except for side effects and I'm nowhere near ready to throw in the towel. Here's to five more years!

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2012 07:20AM carpe_diem wrote: When I was first diagnosed with bc, after many "normal" mammograms and two pleural effusiions, I had cancer in my supraclavicular lymph node and was told it was IIIc, or IV if the lung problem turned out to be related. (Testing of the fluid withdrawn from the lung had been negative for cancer cells, and everthing else they looked for.) Even after the lung nodules lit up in the PET scan, they still weren't sure it wasn't infection until the biopsy showed the same cancer as the breast biopsy.  The confusion about IIIc vs IV is probably because IIIc was added fairly recently and Supraclavicular spread used to be considered stage IV: Brito  from The University of Texas M. D. Anderson Cancer Center, observed significantly better survival after multimodality treatment among 70 patients with solitary ipsilateral supraclavicular metastases at first presentation compared with patients with nonsupraclavicular metastatic disease. Due to concerns regarding undertreatment, Brito et al. advocated the inclusion of supraclavicular disease in the Stage III (rather than Stage IV) category. This recommendation was followed by the International Union Against Cancer in the most recent edition of the TNM Classification of Malignant Tumors; patients with metastases in supraclavicular lymph nodes now are classified as N3c/pN3c, and a new stage (Stage IIIC) that includes N3 (pN3a, pN3b, pN3c) M0 (any T-classification) has been introduced. In previous editions, these malignancies had been classified as distant metastases (M1; Stage IV disease). From van der Sangen MJ, Coebergh JW, Roumen RM, Rutten HJ, Vreugdenhil G, Voogd AC.    Cancer. 2003 Jul 1;98(1):11-7. Department of Radiotherapy, Catharina Hospital, Eindhoven, The Netherlands. So the current trend is to call it IIIc and treat it more aggressively in hopes of curing or greatly extending survival, rather than IV which has generally been treated with palliative care.  Even that is changing as better systemic treatments become available.  After being told since diagnosis that "the horse was out of the barn" and mx was useless, my doctor's now talking about improved survival with mx for patients with limited metastases. I've gone (mostly) vegan and I exercise a lot more.  It won't cure advanced breast cancer, but I feel great and I hope it will give my treatment the best chance of working.  Take a deep breath and look around for people and activities that help you feel your best.  It does sound as if your onc may be a bit out of date; maybe you should look for a second opinion. This must all be pretty frightening, but I know that listening to all the long-term advanced cancer survivors around here keeps my hopes up. Janet

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2012 05:10PM carpe_diem wrote: I think there is a fair amount of truth, with good research behind it, that exercise and a healthy diet can reduce your chances of getting cancer or of having it return if you're diagnosed at an early stage.  Since I was dx at stage IV I've never seen good evidence that losing weight on a healthy diet and being more active are doing anything more for me than helping me feel better along the way.  There is research indicating that they help some people with side effects, and mine have been pretty minor for 21 months on anastrozole with no progression and mets in the lung less active every PET scan. On the other hand, I do know a very active and fit vegetarian who had stage I bc 10 years ago, but I don't think it's a miracle it hasn't returned.  I'm not much for magic ingredients, though, especially when they come with a hefty pricetag . I'm not religious and when friends tell me they are praying for me, I generally suggest that they might instead spend their time helping someone out.  I attend a Unitarian Universalist church, mostly because I like to sing, but I do agree with their tenets, especially, "Service is our prayer."  When my best friend was dying of breast cancer she was a much-loved accompanist and music librarian at a Suzuki School/Youth Orchestra.  There were a number of fundamentalist Christian mothers there who made every effort to convince Sharon (also a UU) that if she just accepted Jesus as her Savior and had true faith, she would be cured.  I found it pretty offensive. Even at my current, fairly humanist, church, I am frequently told that I'm doing well because I have a positive attitude.  Frankly, I think I have a positive attitude because I'm doing well.  My first onc was the terminal, palliative, hand-patting type and I switched pretty fast because of what I considered his negative attitude, but my current MO didn't really suggest miracles were likely.  However, as I continued to do well she did go so far as to suggest I could be in the group of stage IV patients for whom bc is a chronic disease, and I have recently been treated much more aggressively.  I'm just hoping for a few years with good QOL, and then I'll hope for a few more, but no chasing miracles. Janet

But about 25 percent of those with early-stage disease develop metastatic forms, with an estimated 49,000 new diagnoses each year, according to the American Cancer Society. If I understand the statistics, of 100 diagnoses, 5 patients are already stage IV but an additional 25 will eventually become stage IV.  So the initial diagnosis is fairly uncommon, but of all stage IV patients 5/(5+25) = 5/30 = 1/6, or close to 17% were diagnosed initially.  So among our group, you would expect it to be fairly common. Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2012 01:29AM carpe_diem wrote: wrsmith2x, I'm just getting back to bc.org after a mx Nov. 27, but my weight problems were so much like yours I'm responding, even if it is a little late. I have also always struggled with my weight and had never gotten below 200 after my second son was born in 1981.  I gained and lost the same 50 lbs., mostly on low carb diets which worked fine until my stomach was too upset to continue.  Then I'd gain it all back over the next year or two with a few more for company.  I had endometrial cancer in 2006, bladder cancer in 2007 and 2010 along with gall bladder surgery between the bladder cancer dx and surgery, but all I did was continue the yoyo, topping out at 287.  Then in 2010 I had a breast "blob" I was assured (mammogram and ultrasound) was not cancer, two pleural effusions that I was assured were not cancer.  I continued to have shortness of breath and decided it was finally time to try something new, so I started a walking program with my husband and a semi-vegetarian diet - vegetarian meals every other day, and reduced portions.  I lost 25 lbs between August and November and then managed to stabilize for the holidays. By then it was clear that something was seriously wrong with my left breast (inverted nipple, weird shape) and an additional mammogram showed cancer.  It was no surprise that the PET/CT showed activity in the left lung and a biopsy showed the breast cancer had metastasized there. Now I got involved in an exercise and nutrition program at my cancer center in addition to the walking and followed up on a friend's recommendation to check out the Plant Programme, Jane Plant's response to her own breast cancer.  I'm sure there are other good diets out there, but what they all seem to have in common is a plant based regimin with no red meat or processed foods, limited organic poultry and fish, and lots of fruits and vegetables.  My diet totally eliminates dairy, pretty hard for a cheese lover, but some allow low-fat cheese.  For me, it was easier to just avoid it entirely since I love it so much I'd find it hard to stop. Since May 8, 2010 I have lost an additional 80 lbs.  I've again been slowed down by Thanksgiving and surgery (my doctors finally decided that a mx might be useful), but I'm ready to hop back on the bandwagon, hoping to lose about a pound a week with diet and exercise.  Six days after surgery I'm already having to remind myself to take it easy - I have very little pain and lots of energy. Everyone is different, and my only medication for cancer has been anastrozole (arimidex).  My side effects have been minimal, but my NP tells me that increasing exercise and improving diet probably helped with that.  So my advice is not to think about diet and rapid weight loss, but to find support for exercise and diet that will change your lifestyle and gradually reduce your weight. Janet

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2013 03:31PM carpe_diem wrote: I had no trouble getting my insurance to pay for my first PET/CT after my BC diagnosis since I'd been having unexplained pleural effusions, and it did show activity in my supraclavical lymph node which was known to be enlarged.  It took a lung biopsy to verify that the bc had metastatized there, since other inflammations can cause increased uptake, but the lymph node above the collarbone was unlikely to be anything else. Since then, I've occasionally had trouble getting a PET/CT approved, but your doctor can resubmit it as a "peer-to-peer" request where he (or she) talks to a doctor at the insurance company instead of just handling it at a lower level.  This has always worked for me (knock wood ) and is generally faster than just submitting a request for reconsideration, which can take weeks for a reply. Even if the PET/CT shows nothing else, supraclavical lymph node involvement makes it stage IIIc, I think, which gets treated pretty agressively, so it's important to get right on this.  I hope your MO can get the insurance company to see reason. Janet

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2013 05:16PM carpe_diem wrote: As far as I can tell, these lymph nodes are in the abdomen and are not generally connected with breast cancer. See bjr.birjournals.org/content/80... Figure 18. CT image of the abdomen demonstrates the following nodal stations: lateral aortic (light blue); retrocaval (green); lateral caval (pink); pre-aortic (red); pre-caval (dark blue).  Since your signature shows no lymph node involvement in the more typical spots, these are less likely to be metastases from the breast cancer, but I think they are saying they can't rule it out, or it may be an unrelated cancer. Some sort of inflammation could have the same characteristics, and while waiting is hard, repeating the PET/CT in three months or so could clarify the situation. If you have further symptoms you should get need immediate attention.  Given their location and size it would be challenging to biopsy them and waiting might make that unnecessary. Janet

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2014 08:35AM carpe_diem wrote: I just attended a meeting on living with metastatic breast cancer in Rochester, NY, that discussed this question. Some doctors scan regularly, maybe once a year, but the standard treatment is to wait for symptoms and then scan. The theory is that finding mets a little early doesn't affect the outcome and frequent scans expose you to more radiation and may cause cancer. An example was given of a woman who had clear scans and then developed symptoms a few weeks later. Both she and her doctor minimized the problem, since she'd just been given a clean bill of health, and her mets were found later than if they had waited for symptoms and then scanned. On the other hand, a radiologist spoke to the group about treating individual metastases with stereotactic radiation as possibly curative in some cases with one to five mets limited to one organ.  You'd think that would need to be found early, so go figure. I had mets right away and had symptoms (shortness of breath, pleural effusion) months before I was finally diagnosed with bc, but if I hadn't I'd have wanted to be followed at least with regular blood work and maybe tumor markers that might pick up a problem early.

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2013 02:12PM carpe_diem wrote: Scottiee1, Not all lung mets are alike.  I have "pleural thickening" with lots of small nodules and had pleural effusions 8 months before I was finally diagnosed with bc and they were biopsied to show metastasis.  They have become much less active with arimidex (I'm ER+) but they still show up on every PET/CT.  I'm no longer accumulating fluid.  My pleura adhered to the lung on its own, but there is a procedure that can produce the same result - pleurodesis.  Some people have a single lung tumor that can sometimes be surgically removed to good effect, but mine are considered inoperable.  I'm doing well almost 2 years after dx and 30 months after I should have been.  Even if the lung issue is under control, there are still circulating tumor cells that could land elsewhere, so it's important to keep up with treatment and I think diet and exercise have improved things for me, as well.  There are some stage 4 ladies with lung mets on the over five years since dx list, so tell your friend to hang in there and see what her mo suggests. Janet

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2013 11:37AM carpe_diem wrote: My shortness of breath was only with exercise and was relieved by thoracentesis.  If lung mets are causing a pleural effusion (water on the lung), doctors can generally hear it when they listen to your lung, and then it's easily verified by x-ray or ultrasound.  In my case, the pleura adhered to the lung on its own and when the lung biopsy that confirmed bc mets was done there was no need for the pleurodesis to create the adhesion artificially.  I'm not sure that pleural effusion is the only reason for shortness of breath with lung mets, but even if your problem is intermittent you need to have it checked.  Almost three years after my lung problem first showed up (it took almost a year to diagnose) I'm doing well on anastrozole (Arimidex) and exercise has improved my lung capacity even with half the left lung out of commission.

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2013 04:53PM carpe_diem wrote: I've been in a nutrition and exercise program for cancer survivors, mostly bc, for two years now find it a great source of support.  Until recently, I was the only stage 4 bc patient, but another member recently developed bone mets, and there is also a member with folicular lymphoma, which is incurable but treatable - about like mine.  I don't think I've scared anyone away, and we've often experienced the same treatments and side effects.  I know a few other stage 4 patients in the volunteer program, but I'm comfortable with the mixed group. We have parties and regular lunches in addition to exercising three mornings a week, plus monthly weigh-ins and nutrition consultations.  I think it may even make it less frightening for early stage patients to realize that stage 4 is not an immediate death sentence.  Diet and exercise may reduce their chances of recurrence, but if  it does recur or spread, they know that you can live with it and maintain your quality of life.

Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2012 01:05PM carpe_diem wrote: The MO I saw at Memorial Sloan-Kettering said that for ER+ cancers it's worth going through all the hormonals and after that you can start over since cancer cells often lose their resistance to a tx.  In addition, Affinitor has recently been approved for bc and can be added to a hormonal which has previously failed. Some people have practically miraculous responses.  The SE's can be difficult, but if you check out the Affinitor threads you can find ways to minimize them. If they do work, the hormonals are generally easier to tolerate.  I've been Stage IV on arimidex for 19 months with only minor SE's, but I've also made lifestyle changes that I feel support my tx plan.  If your mom isn't feeling up to much, diet and exercise may be the last thing she wants to think of, but talking to a nutritionist and seeing what community services are available in your area could be really worthwhile.

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2014 04:11AM carpe_diem wrote: cypher, You might find this website useful: http://www.xrayrisk.com/calculator/calculator-nor... It gives the radiation dose for common procedures measured in mSv (millisieverts), ranging from 0.001 mSv for a DEXA bone density up to 14.1 mSv for a whole body PET scan. These can add up pretty quickly: if you have a chest CT, that's 7 mSv, but if you have a CT of chest, abdomen, and pelvis you're up to 21 mSv. A bone scan is pretty close to a chest CT, at 6.3 mSv, while a chest x-ray is only 0.1 mSv and a mammogram is 0.4 mSv. I also found this: In a 2009 study from Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston, researchers estimated the potential risk of cancer from CT scans in 31,462 patients over 22 years. For the group as a whole, the increase in risk was slight — 0.7% above the overall lifetime risk of cancer in the United States, which is 42%. But for patients who had multiple CT scans, the increase in risk was higher, ranging from 2.7% to 12%. (In this group, 33% had received more than five CT scans; 5%, more than 22 scans; and 1%, more than 38.) I would say that the younger you are, the more you would like to avoid the high dose scans if some other test will give the information you want.  Ultrasound and MRI's use no radiation.

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2014 05:10AM carpe_diem wrote: In the US Compassionate Allowance applies to stage IV breast cancer and a bunch of other conditions and guarantees you a rapid response. I got my first check in less than a month. It's not necessarily automatic, but I've never heard of anyone being turned down. Your benefits start five months after diagnosis or stopping work, whichever is later, and then you receive Medicare after two years of benefits.  The number of work credits needed for disability benefits depends on your age when you become disabled. Generally you need 40 credits, 20 of which were earned in the last 10 years ending with the year you become disabled. However, younger workers may qualify with fewer credits. I have heard of people being asked to show that they are still disabled after about five years, but most of us would be thrilled to have that problem.

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2012 06:00PM carpe_diem wrote: After my dx in March 2011, I was told that surgery wsn't indicated by my original MO and by the one I'm currently with. Then I started seeing information on the web that retrospective studies showed longer survival with mx for stage IV (30 to 50% longer), and my MO now feels that there is enough evidence to support it in selected cases even if some of the positive results are due to selection bias.  I went to Sloan-Kettering for another opinion and got a fairly balanced idea of thinking on both sides of the question, but the doctor came down on the side of mx in my case: mets only to the lung, stable for 18 months on anastrozole and in good health otherwise.  I just saw my MO Monday and my latet scans and bloodwork show I'm still stable and she's sending me back to a breast surgeon.  My DH asked her for pros and cons and one of the pros made me a lot more enthusiastic about mx.  She said that leaving the tumor in the breast left open the possibility of growth of the tumor either erupting through the skin or tunneling through the chest wall.  I realize that eventually I'll run out of treatments to control my cancer, but this sounds like a bad way to go.  There are dangers in any surgery, but I've had more invasive surgeries and recovered relatively quickly.

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2012 05:17AM carpe_diem wrote: Chickadee, I was diagnosed as stage iv 10 months after being assured that the blob in my breast was not related to cancer and 8 months after being told that there was no sign of cancer in my pleural effusions, so my faith in science was a little chipped around the edges. It may be especially common in stage iv patients to feel that science has failed them, so they might as well check out the pseudo-science possibilities.  When I let friends and family know about my diagnosis, I asked for their experience and advice.  Some of it was off the wall, but several had a loved one with advanced cancer and could speak from personal knowledge.  They helped me find a new cancer center that was more supportive of complementary medicine and suggested supplements and diet changes that were in line with what my onc and the cancer center nutritionist recommended. My DH is a research scientist for a pharmaceutical company recenty acquired by Novartis and I have a PhD in physical chemistry, so we are maybe a bit better prepared than most not to let wishful thinking color our decisions about treatment.  As he tells me, the plural of anecdote is not data. But he also goes walking or biking with me every day and encourages me to stick to a healthy diet. I've also heard about the conspiracy theories and magic cures, but if I'm going to be a guinea pig, I would rather it were in a well-designed study that would produce useful results for others in the same boat. Janet

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2012 01:55AM carpe_diem wrote: This is also complicated by the number of people who are dxed with stage IV so soon after their original dx that you have to feel it was there all along.  My "official" first dx was IIIc in Feb 2011, but since I'd had unexplained pleural effusions starting July 2010 it was pretty clear that stage IV was highly likely and that was checked out before I started treatment.  I've had no agressive treatment, just anastrozole, but now it looks like I may have a mastectomy.  The research isn't clear, since the randomized studies are just getting underway, but retrospective studies show a benefit for mx even at stage IV. It's also hard to compare historic data, since until about 10 years ago IIIc (supraclavical lymph node metastasis) was considered stage IV, and also because more recent data includes much more stage 0 (DCIS) and stage 1 cancers, which presumably were around earlier but weren't detected.  Both of these would tend to make earlier stage IV rates higher.  I'd be interested in a reference for the 10% number.  I can't find anythig that's really up-to-date, but the charts I've seen show the decrease expected.  This is from Komen http://ww5.komen.org/Diagnosis/DistributionOfCancerStagesPopulation.html    Janet

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2012 08:03PM carpe_diem wrote: I was diagnosed with a pleural effusion based on a CT scan for another issue. Once the fluid was drained (twice, for a total of about 2 liters) a new CT scan showed "countless small pleural based nodules on the left side ranging in size from a few mm to 1 cm."  When no signs of disease were found in the infiltrate, my pulmonologist just told me to come back in a year and said that it could not be related to the blob in my breast that had been checked with mammogram and sonogram with negative results.  My PCP wasn't happy with this and sent me to a thoracic surgeon to see about a biopsy, but I got the same response: these are common in people your age (61 then) and too small to biopsy.  A few months later it turned out I did have breast cancer, at least stage IIIC - a mucinous carcinoma that doesn't show up well on mammograms.  The PET scan that followed showed "mild uptake along the pleural surfaces of the left hemithorax" with SUVs of 4.8 and 5.1, but still was considered indeterminate, either inflammatory of metastatic.  The same thoracic surgeon did the biopsy and the pathology report indicated "metastatic mucinous adenocarcinoma showing positive ER/PR and 2+ Her-2-neu, similar to breast primary.  I never did find out why a biopsy was possible then when it wasn't earlier, but I would think that a BC patient with a fairly agressive tumor would at least warrant a PET/CT.  My pleural effusions were probably related to the mucinous character of the tumors, so I don't know if other forms of BC would produce as much fluid.  While Sallyyy's post might have been started in a different spot, I have been looking for a discussion of lung mets and their treatment, particularly the possilbility of surgical, radiation, or cryogenic removal.  If there is another thread discussing this, I'd appreciate a lead.  Janet

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2015 07:53PM carpe_diem wrote: I like bucket list because it propels me into the future. The big item on my list was to retire to New York and build a home on the lot we purchased years ago with a stunning lake view. Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2016 08:31PM carpe_diem wrote: I just got an unanticipated lesson in de-accessing my port and, as longtermsurvivor says, it's a simple procedure. I was near the end of my second week (out of five) of continuous infusion 5-FU when the fanny pack holding my pump and infusion bag fell off the night table. It was 2 AM and I didn't notice a problem then, but at 5:30 it was clear that the bag had sprung a slow leak and there wasn't enough left to get me through to Monday morning. Besides, I had drips of chemotherapy here and there and that's a real no-no. After I looked at the directions for handling spills I called the 24-hour line for guidance and they sent out a nurse to help with the toxic waste clean-up. I did recommend that she wait for daylight. Did I mention the snowstorm and icy roads? She was very helpful and said we'd done a good job following instructions but thought I needed help for getting the tubing and needle out. She showed me how to wear gloves to remove air from the saline and heparin, clamp the tube, disconnect the tube from the pump, clean everything obsessively with alcohol wipes, flush with saline, clean obsessively again, flush with heparin, remove the bandage and take the needle out of the port. Really, it's easier done than said.

Posts.Content: May 19, 2014 02:54AM carpe_diem wrote: exbrnx, Your funeral story reminds me of the Arlington, TX, piano teacher who was expected to die from cancer and planned her own funeral. She recovered but, in a bizarre turn of events, was murdered by a pair of teenagers she took into her home to help. I had heard about the terrible event, but was surprised to get a call at the local Youth Orchestra, where I worked, to say that she had left us a grand piano in her will, but requested that the Youth Orchestra provide a string quartet to play at her funeral. This was on a school day, and in Texas it's hard to get high school students released, so we went with a middle school group of talented 12 and 13-year-olds.  Most of the repertoire was left up to us, but she particularly asked for "Send in the Clowns." Fortunately, the violist also played piano, so he quickly worked up the piece and they played to a large appreciative audience. Then we trucked the piano off to Orchestra Hall.  I'd been thinking about the second movement of the Bach A Minor violin concerto, and maybe Brahms' "How Lovely is Thy Dwelling Place" for my funeral, but I really ought to add, "Send in the Clowns" to the list.  Not that I'm planning to check out anytime soon. But who knows? I could be hit by the proverbial bus!

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2014 05:51AM carpe_diem wrote: I worried about taking disability even though SS suggested it.  I was 62 at the time and mentioned I was applying then because my anticipated lifespan wouldn't take me to full retirement age.  After learning I had stage IV bc, the agent told me about the Compassionate Allowance program and helped with the application, which would pay the full retirement amount.  Now I'm almost 65 and in much better shape than expected, but without this dx I'd probably have received SS for 20 or 25 years and now that would take a major medical miracle! I don't know what support your daughter receives, but she would be eligible for coverage if you were on disability.  SS is an insurance program that you paid into for years and it's supposed to be there for you when life deals you a bad hand.  SS is not in real trouble financially (unlike Medicare) and there are relatively easy fixes for it, so you needn't feel that you'll break the bank if you take what's owed to you.  Would your husband be willing to call the doctor's office to let them know how much this comment upset you? Maybe the woman was having a bad day, but do you want to risk her treating other patients that way?

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2013 06:34PM carpe_diem wrote: I had "normal" mammograms for years and when I found a blob in my breast I had a diagnostic mammogram and ultrasound that showed no problems.  Then I developed pleural effusions that showed no signs of cancer.  It was eight  months after the normal mammogram that I was finally diagnosed with bc and two months later that a lung biopsy showed stage 4 bc.  I had never bothered getting copies of my lab reports until then.  If you read the fine print in the mammogram report it says that 4-8% of tumors don't show up and apparently about half of those aren't visible on ultrasound.  My tumors eventually turned out to be mostly mucinous, which doesn't show up as abnormal but also doesn't often metastasize (go figure ). Like I said, "Absence of evidence is not evidence of absence." I used to support Komen and Planned Parenthood, but now my donations go to Planned Parenthood, American Cancer Society, and American Institute for Cancer Research.  I think it's money well spent.
